This was the case for three brain regions, from which we discarded one for our analyses because it was in the occipital cortex. The two remaining ROIs were in the left SMG (MNI: x=-62, y=-24, z=36) and left area 7 in the superior parietal lobule (MNI: x=-12, y=-64, z=64). To ensure that only brain was included in the ROIs, we centred them two voxels more medially for the left SMG, and one voxel more inferiorly for the left area 7.

Spherical ROI masks were transformed from standard space to each participant’s structural space using a standard-to-structural warp field, and from structural to functional space with a structural-to-functional affine matrix. The resulting transformed masks were thresholded and binarized. Then, motion and physiological noise were partialled out from the filtered functional data. The time-series of each ROI was extracted from the residual filtered functional data, and averaged across voxels. Timeseries data were normalised, and up-sampled 20 times using cubic spline interpolation. The resulting data were epoched into 17 sec windows of 2 sec before and 15 sec after each event of interest (described in GLM section below). We applied ordinary least squares GLMs to each time point, resulting in a time course of beta weights for each regressor. All parametric regressors were normalized (mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1). In all of the following ROI-GLMs, we included constant regressors in addition to the described parametric regressors below.

sec.title: Time course GLMs (ROI-GLMs)
sec.p: We hypothesized that these regions which are involved in processing uncertainty and AD during action generation might also be involved in processing the feedback outcomes. Therefore, our time course analyses were independent of the whole-brain analyses based on which the ROIs were defined. Correlations between regressors for all ROI-GLMs are shown in Figure S8.

Our overall hypothesis is that the brain represents the inferred control belief based on the currently observed feedback difference and the prior inverse self-estimate (Figure 6A). First, we tested whether SMG and area 7 represent the inferred control estimate and its update. Therefore, we ran the following ROI-GLM1, time-locked to the outcome of a current trial (Figure 6B): (26)BOLD∼control+controlupdate where control is the control rating from the next trial and is therefore a measure of what control level participants infer from the currently observed feedback. Control update is the difference between the next trial’s and the current trial’s control rating, and is therefore a measure of how much participants change their control rating based on the currently observed outcomes. All trials in the Control-Other phase are included in this ROI-GLM1.

The goal of our next GLM was to examine if ROI activity correlates with the feedback difference and inverse self, which are the components necessary for control inference. Here, we examined two competing hypotheses (see Figure 6C-D) for how our ROIs might represent the feedback difference at the time of outcome. Firstly, we hypothesized that neural activity might represent the feedback difference as the comparison between normal and AD feedback to infer control (H1, Figure 6C). This means that neural activity does not depend on whether the currently observed outcome is from an AD trial and the previous was from a normal trial or vice versa. Alternatively, neural activity might track feedback differences between outcomes in a simpler comparison of current trial versus previous trial. In this case, neural activity depends only on the temporal order of current and previously seen feedback, and not on the identity of the trial as normal or AD. We tested these two hypotheses in a single GLM time-locked to the outcome phase (ROI-GLM2): (27)BOLD~feedbackdiffADtonormal+feedbackdiffnormaltoAD+inverseself+AD with (28)feedbackdiffADtonormal=normalfeedbackcurrenttrial−ADfeedbackprevioustrial (29)feedbackdiffnormaltoAD=normalfeedbackprevioustrial−ADfeedbackcurrenttrial

Analogously to the behavioural analysis, only switch trials in the Control-Other phase are included in this analysis because these are the trials when participants can observe a feedback difference (between normal and AD trials), which is the critical variable to infer controllability. To test H1 and H2 in one GLM, we defined two regressors for feedback difference which are both computed as the difference of normal minus AD feedback. Feedback diffAD to normal is the feedback difference only on switch trials where the previous trial was AD and the current is normal. In contrast, feedback diffnormal to AD is only defined on trials where the previous trial was normal and the current is AD. Defining the feedback difference separately by the type of switch trial allowed us to pit the two hypotheses H1 and H2 against each other (bar plot in Figure 6E). This is because the average across feedback diffAD to normal and feedback diffnormal to AD is the overall effect in favour of H1, while the average across feedback diffAD to normal and the sign-flipped feedback diffnormal to AD is the overall effect in favour of H2. By only including switch trials into this analysis, we also ensured that any feedback difference related effects cannot be driven by the feedback difference being higher on switch than stay trials. Inverse self is the inverse of the current trial’s self rating from the current trial (i.e. before observing the feedback, computed similarly as for the behavioural analysis) to measure what participants’ prior for their own performance is. AD was included as a regressor of no interest to control for other features that might impact the feedback difference between outcomes.

Next, we investigated the neural correlates of how participants split up the tPE into sPE and oPE according to their known control level in the Self-Other phase. For this, we ran three GLMs. Analogously to the behavioural analysis, we analysed only normal trials during the Self-Other phase and computed sPE and oPE in the same way as for the behaviour. First, we tested whether SMG and area 7 represented the sPE and oPE at the time of outcome. Due to the high correlation between sPE and oPE (r=0.55), we tested their effects in two separate regressions (ROI-GLMs 3 and 4), and jointly within a single regression model (ROI-GLM5) and ensured that similar results were found in all cases.

We also tested an alternative approach for how neural activity might represent the splitting up of the tPE in the outcome phase. In ROI-GLM6, we tested whether there are representations of the tPE and control level, which are used to construct the sPE and oPE.

(33)BOLD∼tPE+control where control is the true control level and tPE is the total prediction error. Analogously to our behavioural analysis, in ROI-GLMs 3 to 6, we analysed only normal trials in the Self-Other phase because this is when the feedback reflects both self and other, and therefore generates a tPE that can be split up into an sPE and oPE in relation to the known control level.

Finally, we tested whether neural activity correlates with feedback in our task, independent of any credit assignment or inference process. A key region that has been implicated in tracking reward is the ventral striatum. To test whether the ventral striatum signals feedback in our task, we extracted activity from an anatomically defined bilateral mask of the nucleus accumbens [74]. We ran the following regression model time locked to the outcome phase (ROI-GLM7): (34)BOLD~feedback+feedbackchange where feedback is the parametric feedback observed on the current trial, and feedback change is the signed difference between the feedback observed on the current compared to the previous trial. To ensure that any effects related to these two regressors are independent of AD, we tested this only on normal trials following normal trials, across Self-Other and Control-Other phases.

sec.title: Leave-one-out (LOO) procedure
sec.p: To test for significance and avoid temporal selection biases in our time course analyses, we used a similar approach to previous studies [17, 34, 74, 75]. For each participant (n=31), we computed the average time course across the remaining participants (n=30). Next, we computed the time point between 4 and 10 sec (unless otherwise specified) when this average time course peaks, and extracted the beta value for the excluded participant at this peak time. This was repeated for all participants, resulting in a set of individual peak values that were determined in an unbiased way. These peak values were tested with a two-tailed one-sample t-test against zero.

caption.title: Structure of the credit assignment task.
caption.p: A) In our task, participants assigned outcomes (overall feedback) to three causes: their own performance, another fictive player’s performance, and their respective control over the feedback. These causes were hidden and latent, and there was only one piece of feedback on each trial. The feedback parametrically varied over trials. B) Each trial started with a rating screen on which participants rated their beliefs about their own control, their own performance, and the other player’s performance. Then, they played one round of a simple game (action phase): In the example here, a ball rolled down a slide and they had to press a button when they believed it had passed the green target cross. A large black box hid the ball’s path which made it impossible to know exactly when the ball passed the cross. This meant that participants had to rely on the feedback shown to them to infer their own performance, alongside the other player’s performance and their own control. At the end of the trial, the overall feedback was shown which was the sum of the participants’ own and the other player’s performance, weighted by their respective control over the feedback. After participants pressed a button to continue, an ITI followed. C) Which ratings participants completed depended on the phase: i) In the beginning of each task block, participants entered the first, ‘Self-Other phase’. Here, they were informed of the control level but they learned about their own and the other’s performance level. This task phase allowed us to determine how participants assign credit to themselves and a new other player while knowing their control. Note that in the task, real faces were shown for the other players on each rating screen (here substituted with icons). ii) In the Control-Other phase, participants played with a new other player and their control was reset and unknown. In this phase, participants knew their own true performance level because of the preceding Self-only trials they had played between Self-Other and Control-Other phase. In the Self-only trials, participants played alone, and the feedback only reflected their own performance. This meant that they could double-check if they had accurately inferred their own performance level in the preceding Self-Other phase, and adjust their beliefs accordingly. Subsequently, therefore, in the following Control-Other phase, they inferred the new other player’s performance and their new control over the feedback. D) Participants completed four blocks, each of which was divided into three phases, signalled to participants (example block is shown here). Each block started with the Self-Other phase, after which followed Self-only trials, ending with the Control-Other phase. Analyses are conducted on behavioural and neural data from the Self-Other and Control-Other phases when, respectively, participants were inferring their own and the other’s performance levels from the feedback they received or inferring the other performance level and the control from the feedback.

caption.title: Credit assignment behaviour.
caption.p: A) Hypothesized cognitive process and behaviour. Participants’ beliefs (measured as their ratings) together form an estimate of the feedback they expect to receive (estimated feedback). At the time of the outcome, the discrepancy between their estimated feedback and the actual feedback results in a total prediction error (tPE). Participants should use the tPE to update their beliefs about themselves (their own performance level), their own control, and the other player’s performance level. In the, first, Self-Other phase, when participants know about their own control, they can use this knowledge to split up the tPE into a PE assigned to themselves (sPE) and the other (oPE). B) Participants’ estimated feedback followed the observed mean feedback throughout the task (example block 3 out of 4, means plotted as lines, standard deviation (SD) plotted as shaded interval). C) Participants’ mean ratings (lines) and their SD (shaded interval) for the same example block as in B. Figure S3 shows the averaged individual ratings and estimated feedback for all task blocks. D) Over time, participants improved the accuracy, both of the estimated feedback and the individual component ratings of self-performance, other performance, and control, from observing the feedback. Overall, the estimated feedback improved more from the start of a phase to the end than did the individual component ratings individually. Accuracy is defined as the inverse of the absolute rating errors, normalised by the highest error possible. E) Participants updated their beliefs about self (left) and other (right) more positively after a high positive tPE on the previous trial (main effect of tPE on rating updates). As expected if participants assign credit appropriately, they here also take into account their control level over the feedback, and attribute more of the tPE to themselves (and less to the other) if they themselves have more control (interaction effects tPE*Control on self update, and tPE*(1-Control) on other update). Simulated data from an optimal Bayesian observer model (“Active learner”) show the same result pattern as participants (open black dots). We used ANOVAs (with sample, fMRI versus online, as between-participant factor) and evaluated the p-value of the intercept term to assess the significance of participants’ beta estimates (i.e. standardized regression coefficients) irrespective of sample. For completeness, the main effects of Control on self and 1-Control on other are described in the supplements (section ‘Control effect on self and other ratings’). n=31 MRI, n=36 online; *, p<0.05; **, p<0.01; ***, p<0.001.

caption.title: Active disambiguation (AD).
caption.p: A) We hypothesized that participants made deliberate mistakes in the games to assign credit better. In the game shown here, they could press the button too late to see how much of a difference this makes to the feedback. We refer to such a trial as an active disambiguation (AD) trial. During the task, AD trials were detected whenever participants made extreme errors during the games that were then transformed into a zero self-performance (see Methods for details). Figure S4 illustrates how extreme errors were defined as AD trials, and data from an example participant. B) We hypothesized that participants generated more AD trials under high uncertainty, and that AD trials helped them reduce uncertainty and assign credit better (lower rating errors). C) We indeed found that participants generated AD in phases when the feedback was ambiguous (Self-Other and Control-Other phases). Whenever the feedback was certain (Self-only trials), AD dropped strikingly. D) After finishing the task, participants reported how many AD trials they generated per game. We found that their subjective reports of AD trials were significantly correlated with the objective frequency of AD trials identified in their behaviour. E) Trial-wise uncertainty, extracted from the active Bayesian learning model, is reduced if the previous trial or the one before was an AD trial. F) Crucially, participants’ rating errors are reduced after AD, which shows that they can use the additional information afforded by AD (similar to the simulated data from the Active learner model, black open dots). In panels E and F, we tested the significance of the beta estimates (irrespective of sample) by evaluating the intercept terms from ANOVAs with sample (MRI or online) as between-participant factor. Note that in both E and F we did not find a significant group difference between the samples (all p>0.05). Panel D includes n=29 MRI and n=64 online participants with otherwise excluded participants (that e.g. never did AD, see Methods for details); Panels C, E, F: n=31 MRI, n=36 online; n.s., not significant; **, p<0.01; ***, p<0.001.

caption.title: Inferring control.
caption.p: A) Optimally, one can infer one’s control level from observing the difference between trials when doing one’s best (‘normal trials’) vs. making a deliberate mistake (‘AD trial’). On a normal trial, the observed feedback is: normal feedback = Self × Control + Other × (1-Control). On an AD trial, the participant plays so badly that Self = 0, which results in the AD feedback being: AD feedback = Other × (1-Control). This means that on an AD trial, the feedback only reflects the other player’s performance, weighted by their control. Therefore, the difference between feedback on a normal versus an AD trial corresponds to the participant’s own performance weighted by their control (Self × Control, see green text). This means that control can be inferred by observing the difference between a normal and an AD trial, taking into account one’s own performance (Control = Feedback difference / Self). B) Intuitively, low control can be inferred if there is barely any difference between feedback on a normal versus an AD trial. C) To test whether participants used the strategy depicted in A, we analysed their control ratings with a hierarchical regression (MRI and online samples were pooled here). We examined whether, after ‘switch’ trials (either AD trials following normal trials, or vice-versa), the next trials’ control ratings could be predicted by the observed feedback difference (normal feedback – AD feedback) and the inverse self-rating, and their interaction. As expected, participants showed effects similar to the optimal Active learner, meaning that they inferred their control from the feedback difference between AD and normal trials, taking into account their own overall game performance. As control analyses, we ran the same analyses on simulated data from two computational models that made wrong assumptions about AD trials. The passive learner ignored AD trials during learning, while the ignorant learner assumed that AD trials were in fact normal trials. Importantly, all agents (participants, as well as the active, passive and ignorant learners) received the same observations, which corresponded to the feedback participants actually received. We found that indeed the passive and ignorant learner showed different learning patterns: the interaction effect, Feedback difference * Inverse Self, differentiated between, on the one hand, participants and the Active learner, and, on the other hand, the Passive and Ignorant learners. While participants and the Active learner had a significant positive interaction effect, the Passive learner had no significant effect, and the Ignorant learner had a significantly negative effect. D) Interaction effect Feedback difference * Inverse Self. Note that for easier interpretation, here, we relabelled the legend of ‘inverse self’ regressor to ‘self’ and flipped its levels accordingly (e.g. ‘low self’ is the effect of ‘high inverse self’). Both participants and the Active learner infer a low control when there is a lower difference between normal and AD feedback. If there is a large difference, they infer a high control – but this depends on the level of their own performance. If low self-performance is assumed and there is still a high feedback difference, then a higher control is inferred to account for a high feedback difference. If, however, high self-performance is assumed and the feedback difference is high, then a slightly lower control can be inferred. The ignorant and passive learner show markedly different behaviour in this interaction effect. Overall, this means that, like the Active learner, participants were able to take advantage of the additional information AD trials offer in order to infer controllability. n=31 MRI, n=36 online; n.s., 95% CI includes 0; ***, 99.9% CI excludes 0.

caption.title: Whole-brain maps for average uncertainty and AD at the time of action.
caption.p: Since we found that participants generated AD trials under uncertainty in both task phases, we collapsed the data across both Self-Other and Control-Other phase in this neural analysis (see Methods for full details). A) i) Activity in the left SMG related to higher uncertainty. ii) Lower uncertainty (higher certainty) was reflected in dmPFC and left lOFC. B) i) We also found bilateral activation related to AD in SMG (with a peak in TPJ in the right hemisphere). ii) Additionally, we found AD-related activity in bilateral dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC), extending to dorsomedial PFC dmPFC, and adjacent dACC, bilateral anterior insula, and lOFC. The peak coordinates of significant clusters can be found in Table S1. n=31 MRI, whole-brain effects are cluster corrected with z>3.1 and p<0.05; effects are time-locked to the time of action, when participants played the games, and are across Self-Other and Control-Other phase.

caption.title: Representations of control, feedback difference and inverse self in the SMG at the time of outcome in the Control-Other phase.
caption.p: A) We used time-course analyses to identify the neural correlates of how participants infer their control from feedback difference and the inverse self. Since our whole-brain analyses showed that the SMG represents uncertainty and AD at the time of action, we selected this region as an ROI for the time-course analyses on the outcome phase. B) First, we tested whether at the time of outcome (ROI-GLM1), the SMG represents participants’ inferred control levels (next trial’s control rating) and the updating of the control estimate (difference between current and next trial’s control rating). We indeed found that SMG tracks the inferred control estimate (left panel) and the degree of control level updating (right panel) at the time of outcome. These activity patterns remained unchanged whether control and control updated were examined in the same or separate GLMs. C) In a new GLM (ROI-GLM2), we next tested whether SMG also represents the components necessary for inferring control. We compared two neural hypotheses for how neural activity can track the difference in feedback between trials. Our first neural sub-hypothesis (H1) is that neural activity tracks feedback difference as the difference between normal and AD trials (left). This means that the neural activity does not depend on order: whether a normal trial followed an AD trial, or vice-versa (right). D) Alternatively (H2), neural activity might track the feedback difference in a simpler manner, by comparing the currently observed feedback to the feedback from the previous trial. We used a single GLM (ROI-GLM2) to test these two hypotheses. For this, we computed feedback difference as normal vs AD (according to H1) in all panels. However, we split trial transitions between AD to normal trial transitions and vice versa, because H1 and H2 make different predictions between those trial types. E) At the outcome time (ROI-GLM2), the SMG represents the feedback difference as normal vs AD feedback in accordance with H1 (left). When aggregating the participants’ peak amplitudes using a LOO procedure, we found a significant effect of feedback difference in accordance with H1 rather than H2 (right). Note that the shown effects of feedback difference and control at the time of outcome (panels E and B left) have low regressor correlations (r<0.3, Figure S8A), and are run on different trial selections (control on all trials, feedback difference on switch trials only). F) In the same GLM (ROI-GLM2), we found that SMG also tracks participants’ prior inverse self-estimate (current trial’s inverse self rating) in the outcome phase. n=31 MRI; error bars and shaded intervals show s.e.m. across participants; n.s.; not significant; ***, p<0.001; effects are time locked to the outcome phase; in panel A all trials from the Control-Other phase are included; in panels E-F only switch trials in the Control-Other phase are included.

caption.title: Representations of sPE and oPE in the SMG during the outcome phase in the Self-Other phase.
caption.p: In the Self-Other phase, the key credit assignment problem that participants face is to assign credit to themselves and other people according to their control. On normal trials, they split up the tPE into a sPE and oPE according to their known control (see also Figure 2A and E). We therefore tested whether BOLD activity in the left SMG is modulated by sPE and oPE. Since sPE and oPE are correlated with r=0.55, we tested this both with two separate GLMs containing either sPE but not oPE and vice versa, and a GLM in which both variables were included. All the analyses, however, led to the same conclusion illustrated in the next two panels. A) We found that at the time of the outcome, activation of the left SMG is significantly related to the sPE (ROI-GLM3). B) In a separate GLM, we found that SMG BOLD activity is significantly modulated by the oPE (ROI-GLM4). C) In a separate analysis, we found that the SMG does not represent the tPE which is the sum of sPE and oPE (ROI-GLM5). This is an interesting feature and together with panels A and B suggests that the SMG is involved in belief updating in an agent-based manner, rather than the total outcome per se. n=31 MRI; error bars and shaded intervals show s.e.m. across participants; effects are time locked to the outcome phase and analogously to our behavioural analysis, only normal trials in the Self-Other phase are included.
